<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/52  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 411, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2023  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 636]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Two identical beakers, each of mass \(M,\) are attached to each other using string and suspended from a pulley, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 114, 791, 408]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 425, 591, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 456, 920, 490]]<|/det|>
The beakers are held at rest at a height \(h\) above a surface. Cooking oil of volume \(V\) is added to one of the beakers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 502, 920, 536]]<|/det|>
The beakers are released so that the beaker with the oil begins to fall. The speed of the beaker as it reaches the surface is \(z\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 549, 566, 567]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(z\) is related to \(V\) by the relationship

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 571, 559, 603]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{2h}{z^2} = \frac{2M}{abV} + \frac{1}{b}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 610, 361, 626]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 640, 693, 658]]<|/det|>
Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between z and V.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 670, 625, 689]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 702, 698, 720]]<|/det|>
Explain how the results could be used to determine values for \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 733, 384, 751]]<|/det|>
In your plan you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 764, 393, 781]]<|/det|>
· the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 793, 410, 810]]<|/det|>
· the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 822, 346, 839]]<|/det|>
· the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 852, 351, 868]]<|/det|>
· the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 881, 447, 898]]<|/det|>
· any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 782, 91]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the discharge of capacitors in the circuit shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[369, 102, 625, 330]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 352, 532, 370]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 382, 500, 402]]<|/det|>
The capacitors have capacitances \(C_{\mathrm{A}}\) and \(C_{\mathrm{B}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 413, 571, 432]]<|/det|>
The student closes the switch to charge the capacitors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 920, 479]]<|/det|>
The switch is opened and a stop-watch is started. The capacitors discharge through the resistor of resistance \(R\). At a fixed time \(t\) the voltmeter reading \(V\) is recorded.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 490, 621, 509]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated for different values of \(C_{\mathrm{A}}\) and \(C_{\mathrm{B}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 521, 767, 540]]<|/det|>
For each combination of \(C_{\mathrm{A}}\) and \(C_{\mathrm{B}}\), the combined capacitance \(C\) is calculated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 552, 576, 571]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(C\) and \(V\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 577, 556, 604]]<|/det|>
\[V = I_0\mathrm{Re}^{-\frac{t}{CR}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 615, 473, 633]]<|/det|>
where \(I_0\) is the initial current in the resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 645, 146, 664]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 644, 665, 664]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(\ln V\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\frac{1}{C}\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 675, 611, 694]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 850, 917, 868]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 880, 917, 899]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 897, 920, 914]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 536, 91]]<|/det|> Values of \(C_{\mathrm{A}}\), \(C_{\mathrm{B}}\) and \(V\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 102, 541, 120]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 128, 873, 435]]<|/det|>
\(C_{\mathrm {A}}/10^{-4}\mathrm {F}\)\(C_{\mathrm {B}}/10^{-4}\mathrm {F}\)\(\frac {1}{C}/10^{4}\mathrm {F}^{-1}\)\(V/V\)In \((V/V)\)
2.22.22.45 ± 0.05
2.23.32.75 ± 0.05
2.25.63.05 ± 0.05
3.33.33.10 ± 0.05
3.35.63.50 ± 0.05
5.65.63.85 ± 0.05
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 450, 495, 470]]<|/det|> The relationship between C, \(C_{\mathrm{A}}\) and \(C_{\mathrm{B}}\) is <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 483, 556, 518]]<|/det|> \[\frac{1}{C} = \frac{C_{\mathrm{A}} + C_{\mathrm{B}}}{C_{\mathrm{A}}C_{\mathrm{B}}}.\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 529, 710, 562]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \(\frac{1}{C} /10^{4}\mathrm{F}^{-1}\) and In (V/V) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 574, 536, 593]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in In (V/V). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 574, 920, 593]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 604, 144, 623]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 603, 180, 623]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 600, 546, 625]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of In (V/V) against \(\frac{1}{C} /10^{4}\mathrm{F}^{-1}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 636, 447, 655]]<|/det|> Include error bars for In (V/V). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 636, 920, 655]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 667, 180, 685]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 666, 920, 700]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 682, 920, 700]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 712, 180, 731]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 712, 920, 746]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 915, 922, 934]]<|/det|>
gradient = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 73, 180, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 910, 91]]<|/det|>
Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Do not include the absolute uncertainty.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 212, 922, 231]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 244, 146, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 244, 185, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 244, 920, 278]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of \(R\) and \(I_0\). Include appropriate units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 291, 349, 308]]<|/det|>
Data: \(t = (30 \pm 1) \text{s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 444, 917, 463]]<|/det|>
<form>R = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 476, 920, 495]]<|/det|>
<form>I_0 = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 494, 920, 511]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 523, 181, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 523, 551, 541]]<|/det|>
Determine the percentage uncertainty in \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 662, 920, 681]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty in \(R =\) ................................................. % [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 694, 146, 712]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 693, 920, 727]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated with the same value of \(t\). Determine the combined capacitance \(C\) that gives a value of \(V\) of 1.20V.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 848, 920, 866]]<|/det|>
<form>C = .................................................... F [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 876, 920, 894]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 15]
